node.title: Gabon is the last bastion of endangered African forest elephants
node.alt: A African forest elephant walks in front of some trees, partially obscured by long grass
node.description: African forest elephants are critically endangered,Â but a new study has found that the heavily forested central African nation of Gabon is a last stronghold, with 95,000 animals identified.
node.content:
["Loss of habitat and poaching have made African forest elephants a critically endangered species, yet the dense forests of Gabon remain a \"last stronghold\" for the magnificent creatures.", "New research has concluded the population of elephants in\u00a0the\u00a0sparsely populated nation, in the Congo River Basin, is much higher than previous estimates.", "Counting forest elephants is a far bigger challenge than surveying plains-dwelling savanna elephants from the air.", "It takes difficult and dirty scientific work that doesn't involve laying eyes on the elusive animals, which\u00a0flee at the slightest whiff of human scent.", "Instead, for years researchers have been trekking through dense undergrowth collecting dung from Gabon's forest elephants and analysing the DNA from thousands of samples to determine the number of individual elephants in each plot of land examined.", "The survey, by the New York-based Wildlife Conservation Society (WCS) and the National Parks of Gabon, found that the country of about 2.3 million people harbours about 95,000 forest elephants.", "", "
Research has found that some 95,000 African forest elephants can still be found in Gabon.(AP: Jerome Delay)
", "Previous estimates put the population at 50,000 to 60,000 \u2014\u00a0or about 60 per cent\u00a0of the world's remaining African forest elephants.", "Herds have\u00a0been virtually decimated elsewhere in the region Gabon shares with conflict-ridden countries such as Cameroon, Congo and Central African Republic, according to researchers.", "Central Africa has the largest number of forest elephants in the world, although figures have fallen by more than 86 per cent\u00a0over a 31-year period, according to the International Union for Conservation of Nature, which cites increasing threats of poaching and habitat loss.", "The latest new survey in Gabon is the \"first nationwide DNA-based assessment of a free-ranging large mammal in Africa,\" according to the researchers.", "The technology is also being used to count elephants and tigers in India.", "\"Gabon is quite unique, certainly for forest elephants. But actually across Africa where elephants occur, it's very unique in that \u2026 what we call potential elephant habitat pretty much covers the entire country,\" said Emma Stokes, the WCS Africa regional director.", "", "
Emma Stokes of the WCS gets out the way of an approaching African forest elephant, which will flee if it\u00a0senses\u00a0humans are close.(AP: Jerome Delay)
", "\"We found elephants were distributed across almost 90 per cent of the total surface area of the country.", "\"And\u00a0Gabon has forest cover of up to 88 per cent of the country. That's very unusual.\"", "In Gabon, tourists may still see some elephants on the beaches and coastal forests of the Atlantic coast but, unlike their bigger savanna cousins that roam the plains of southern Africa in abundance, most forest elephants live in dense forests, so counting them is painstaking work.", "The solution: Trail their dung for genetic material.", "
Researchers want 'steaming fresh' dung for analysis
", "", "
Research teams would spend a month at a time trekking through Gabon's remote bushland.(AP: Jerome Delay)
", "For three years, research teams would spend a month in the bush, walking 12 kilometres a day seeking elephant faecal samples, breaking only for a week at a time.", "The team trudged through patches of savanna, thickets, densely wooded wetlands and rivers, following elephant tracks marked by broken tree branches, old dung piles and footprints, looking for fresh dung.", "\"We got some dung here,\" Fabrice Menzeme, a ranger, shouted after walking for about 3\u00a0kilometres in Pongara National Park on the Atlantic coast during fieldwork in 2020.", "", "
The dung needs to be \"steaming fresh\"\u00a0for researchers to collect.(AP: Jerome Delay)
", "Animated team members rushed in. Upon closer inspection, disappointment followed. The dung was more than a day old.", "Researchers want the dung \"steaming fresh\",\u00a0Ms Stokes said.", "The faecal swabs were put into small test tubes and taken to a government wildlife genetic analysis laboratory in the capital, Libreville, where scientists extracted DNA from about 2,500 samples collected countrywide.", "Extracting DNA from dung samples is \"a bit like a cooking recipe\", with several steps needed to remove vegetation and seeds, as well as bacteria or organisms that develop on the dung, said Stephanie Bourgeois, a research scientist with the parks agency and co-author of the research paper.", "\"That's why you have to clean them and try to purify your DNA before you do your analysis,\" Ms Bourgeois said at the laboratory.", "", "
A lab technician prepares a sample of elephant dung from Gabon's Pongara National Park for DNA testing in Libreville.(AP: Jerome Delay)
", "\"DNA is unique for every individual, the same for humans as it is for elephants. So DNA is just a tool to help us identify individuals and the number of times we sample each of these individuals.", "\"We use a complex statistical model and from this we estimate the number of elephants that are in the area we sampled.\"", "
Gabon has elephant problems, despite promising numbers
", "This is Gabon's first nationwide elephant census in 30 years.", "Only 14 per cent\u00a0of the elephant habitat in the country had been surveyed in the last decade, according to researchers.", "Previous surveys relied on dung counts, which can be more expensive, more difficult and less reliable than DNA sampling on large-scale surveys, they said.", "John Poulsen, associate professor of tropical ecology at Duke University's Nicholas School of the Environment, who was not involved in the research, said\u00a0\"the government of Gabon now has an enormous responsibility for conserving forest elephants in the face of poaching, and especially human-elephant conflict and crop-raiding\".", "", "
African forest elephants are rarely seen owing to their hesitancy around humans.(AP: Jerome Delay)
", "About 65\u00a0to 70\u00a0per cent of all African forest elephants surviving today live in Gabon, according to Lee White, Gabon's minister of water and forests.", "\"That's an indication of the fact that Gabon has resisted the slaughter and the tragedy that has played out in the countries around Gabon,\" Mr White said.", "Conservation efforts include massive public awareness campaigns and efforts to deter cross-border poachers.", "\"You see it around Africa. Countries that have lost their elephants, have lost control of their natural resources, have often actually lost control of their countries,\" Mr White said.", "But Gabon is facing elephant problems of its own in addition to cross-border poaching for ivory, which Mr White said had declined since China banned ivory imports.", "Mr White said\u00a0human-elephant conflicts killed about 10 people a year.", "\"When I go into rural Gabon, I get a lot of angry people who are screaming at me because the elephants have eaten their crops and, tragically, even occasionally have killed their relatives.\"", "One reason elephants are raiding village crops, Mr White said, may be that global warming has dramatically reduced the abundance of forest fruit over the past 40 years.", "\"So, it looks like climate change is starting to impact the forest,\" he said.", "\"And that means the elephants are hungry.\"", "AP"]
